summary: The appeal concerned garnishee proceedings involving â‚¤7 7s. 0d. held in court as proceeds of execution from a writ of Pi Pa issued for the respondent, Mumni Ayinde. The appellant, E. J. Alex Taylor, sought to attach the funds through a motion in a suit to which he was not a party. The West Africa Court of Appeal held that money in custodia legis belongs to the defendant and can only be attached by a creditor who has obtained judgment and follows proper execution procedures. The appeal was dismissed because the appellant's motion was incompetent, and the respondent was awarded costs of half a guinea.
rationaleHighlights: Money in custodia legis is treated as property of the defendant
Only a judgment creditor can attach funds held in court
A non-party cannot initiate attachment via motion in an unrelated suit
Proper legal process requires initiating a separate suit for execution
The original court correctly dismissed the incompetent motion
Appellate court did not assess merits, only procedural validity
Dismissing the appeal maintains procedural integrity
Award of costs affirms procedural sanction
confidenceNotes: High confidence; information is directly extracted from the judgment text with clear procedural and jurisdictional context. Case predates modern Ghana's independence but falls under Gold Coast jurisdiction, relevant to Ghanaian legal history.
